verses.text: There was a man from the hill country of Ephraim whose name was Micah.
verses.comment: Micah's name is transliterated; Ephraim is the same as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: He said to his mother, 'The eleven hundred pieces of silver that were taken from you, about which you pronounced a curse and spoke it in my hearing—look, that silver is with me; I took it.' And his mother said, 'May the LORD bless you, my son!'
verses.comment: Retains the phrase 'pieces of silver' for translation accuracy.

verses.text: So he returned the eleven hundred pieces of silver to his mother, and his mother said, 'I devoted this silver to the LORD from my hand for my son, to make a carved image and a metal image. Now, I will return it to you.'
verses.comment: Uses 'carved image' and 'metal image' to reflect Hebrew 'pesel' and 'massekah'.

verses.text: When he returned the silver to his mother, she took two hundred pieces of silver and gave them to a silversmith, who made a carved image and a metal image. They were placed in Micah’s house.
verses.comment: Specific about the amount used for the idols, in accordance with the Hebrew text.

verses.text: This man Micah had a shrine, and he made an ephod and household gods, and installed one of his sons as his priest.
verses.comment: 'Shrine' renders 'Beth-Elohim' as 'house of gods,' 'ephod' and 'household gods' kept literal.

verses.text: In those days there was no king in Israel. Everyone did what was right in his own eyes.
verses.comment: Literal wording preserved, staying true to the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Now there was a young man from Bethlehem in Judah, of the family of Judah, who was a Levite. He was staying there.
verses.comment: Clarifies he is a Levite residing in Bethlehem, per original intent.

verses.text: The man left the town of Bethlehem in Judah to find a place to stay. As he traveled, he came to the hill country of Ephraim, to Micah’s house.
verses.comment: Translates literally, with 'find a place to stay' reflecting Hebrew 'gur' (to sojourn).

verses.text: Micah said to him, 'Where do you come from?' He replied, 'I am a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, and I am looking for a place to stay.'
verses.comment: Phrasing kept natural and accurate to spoken dialogue in original.

verses.text: Micah said to him, 'Stay with me and be a father and a priest to me. I will give you ten pieces of silver a year, a suit of clothes, and your living.' So the Levite went in.
verses.comment: 'Be a father and a priest' uses idiom for respect; salary details included.

verses.text: The Levite agreed to stay with the man, and the young man became like one of his sons.
verses.comment: Clarifies the Levite's relationship with Micah per the Hebrew.

verses.text: Micah installed the Levite, and the young man became his priest and lived in Micah’s house.
verses.comment: Stays close to original Hebrew; 'installed' = 'filled the hand.'

verses.text: And Micah said, 'Now I know that the LORD will do me good, because I have a Levite as priest.'
verses.comment: Literal translation; faith placed in Levite as priest.
